</p><p>The larger scope of Aeschylus as a dramatist revisiting the myth of Prometheus in the age of Athenian prominence has been discussed by William Lynch.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-33"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>31<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Lynch's general thesis concerns the rise of humanist and secular tendencies in Athenian culture and society which required the growth and expansion of the mythological and religious tradition as acquired from the most ancient sources of the myth stemming from Hesiod. For Lynch, modern scholarship is hampered by not having the full trilogy of Prometheus by Aeschylus, the last two parts of which have been lost to antiquity. Significantly, Lynch further comments that although the Prometheus trilogy is not available, the <i>Orestia</i> trilogy by Aeschylus remains available and may be assumed to provide significant insight into the overall structural intentions which may be ascribed to the Prometheus trilogy by Aeschylus as an author of significant consistency and exemplary dramatic erudition.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-34"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>32<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Marble_group_of_the_freeing_of_Prometheus_from_Pergamon_(AvP_VII_168).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="./wikipedia_test_files/Marble_group_of_the_freeing_of_Prometheus_from_Pergamon_(AvP_VII_168).jpg" decoding="async" width="260" height="209" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Marble_group_of_the_freeing_of_Prometheus_from_Pergamon_%28AvP_VII_168%29.jpg/500px-Marble_group_of_the_freeing_of_Prometheus_from_Pergamon_%28AvP_VII_168%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Marble_group_of_the_freeing_of_Prometheus_from_Pergamon_%28AvP_VII_168%29.jpg/960px-Marble_group_of_the_freeing_of_Prometheus_from_Pergamon_%28AvP_VII_168%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2768" data-file-height="2228"></a><figcaption>Sculptural group of Prometheus's liberation, 2nd-1st century BC, now in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin" title="Berlin">Berlin</a>.</figcaption></figure>
<p><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harold_Bloom" title="Harold Bloom">Harold Bloom</a>, in his research guide for Aeschylus, has summarised some of the critical attention that has been applied to Aeschylus concerning his general philosophical import in Athens.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-35"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>33<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> As Bloom states, "Much critical attention has been paid to the question of theodicy in Aeschylus. For generations, scholars warred incessantly over 'the justice of Zeus,' unintentionally blurring it with a monotheism imported from Judeo-Christian thought. The playwright undoubtedly had religious concerns; for instance, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jacqueline_de_Romilly" title="Jacqueline de Romilly">Jacqueline de Romilly</a><sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-36"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>34<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> suggests that his treatment of time flows directly out of his belief in divine justice. But it would be an error to think of Aeschylus as sermonising. His Zeus does not arrive at decisions which he then enacts in the mortal world; rather, human events are themselves an enactment of divine will."<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-37"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>35<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>According to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Rosenmeyer" class="mw-redirect" title="Thomas Rosenmeyer">Thomas Rosenmeyer</a>, regarding the religious import of Aeschylus, "In Aeschylus, as in Homer, the two levels of causation, the supernatural and the human, are co-existent and simultaneous, two ways of describing the same event." Rosenmeyer insists that ascribing portrayed characters in Aeschylus should not conclude them to be either victims or agents of theological or religious activity too quickly. As Rosenmeyer states: "[T]he text defines their being. For a critic to construct an Aeschylean theology would be as quixotic as designing a typology of Aeschylean man. The needs of the drama prevail."<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-38"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>36<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In a rare comparison of Prometheus in Aeschylus with Oedipus in Sophocles, Harold Bloom states that "Freud called <i>Oedipus</i> an 'immoral play,' since the gods ordained incest and parricide. Oedipus therefore participates in our universal unconscious sense of guilt, but on this reading so do the gods" [...] "I sometimes wish that Freud had turned to Aeschylus instead, and given us the Prometheus complex rather than the Oedipus complex."<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-39"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>37<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p><a href="https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karl-Martin_Dietz" class="extiw" title="de:Karl-Martin Dietz">Karl-Martin Dietz</a> states that in contrast to Hesiod's, in Aeschylus' oeuvre, Prometheus stands for the "Ascent of humanity from primitive beginnings to the present level of civilisation."<sup id="cite_ref-Karl-Martin_Dietz_1989,_p._66_25-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-Karl-Martin_Dietz_1989,_p._66-25"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>24<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Plato_and_philosophy">Plato and philosophy</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Prometheus&action=edit&section=12" title="Edit section: Plato and philosophy"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olga_Raggio" title="Olga Raggio">Olga Raggio</a>, in her study "The Myth of Prometheus", attributes Plato in the <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Protagoras_(dialogue)" title="Protagoras (dialogue)">Protagoras</a></i> as an important contributor to the early development of the Prometheus myth.<sup id="cite_ref-Raggio_40-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-Raggio-40"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>38<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Raggio indicates that many of the more challenging and dramatic assertions which Aeschylean tragedy explores are absent from Plato's writings about Prometheus.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-41"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>39<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>
As summarised by Raggio,<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1244412712">.mw-parser-output .templatequote{overflow:hidden;margin:1em 0;padding:0 32px}.mw-parser-output .templatequotecite{line-height:1.5em;text-align:left;margin-top:0}@media(min-width:500px){.mw-parser-output .templatequotecite{padding-left:1.6em}}</style></p><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>After the gods have moulded men and other living creatures with a mixture of clay and fire, the two brothers Epimetheus and Prometheus are called to complete the task and distribute among the newly born creatures all sorts of natural qualities. Epimetheus sets to work but, being unwise, distributes all the gifts of nature among the animals, leaving men naked and unprotected, unable to defend themselves and to survive in a hostile world. Prometheus then steals the fire of creative power from the workshop of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Athena" title="Athena">Athena</a> and Hephaistos and gives it to mankind.</p></blockquote><p> Raggio then goes on to point out Plato's distinction of creative power (<i>techne</i>), which is presented as superior to merely natural instincts (<i>physis</i>).
</p><p>For Plato, only the virtues of "reverence and justice can provide for the maintenance of a civilised society  and these virtues are the highest gift finally bestowed on men in equal measure".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERaggio195845_42-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-FOOTNOTERaggio195845-42"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>40<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The ancients by way of Plato believed that the name <i>Prometheus</i> derived from the Greek <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prefix" title="Prefix">prefix</a> <i>pro</i>- (before) + <i>manthano</i> (intelligence) and the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent_suffix" class="mw-redirect" title="Agent suffix">agent suffix</a> -<i>eus</i>, thus meaning "Forethinker".
</p><p>In his dialogue titled <i>Protagoras</i>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plato" title="Plato">Plato</a> contrasts Prometheus with his dull-witted brother <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epimetheus_(mythology)" class="mw-redirect" title="Epimetheus (mythology)">Epimetheus</a>, "Afterthinker".<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-43"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>41<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-44"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>42<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In Plato's dialogue <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Protagoras_(dialogue)" title="Protagoras (dialogue)">Protagoras</a></i>, Protagoras asserts that the gods created humans and all the other animals, but it was left to Prometheus and his brother <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epimetheus_(mythology)" class="mw-redirect" title="Epimetheus (mythology)">Epimetheus</a> to give defining attributes to each. As no physical traits were left when the pair came to humans, Prometheus decided to give them fire and other civilising arts.<sup id="cite_ref-titan_45-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-titan-45"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>43<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Athenian_religious_dedication_and_observance">Athenian religious dedication and observance</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Prometheus&action=edit&section=13" title="Edit section: Athenian religious dedication and observance"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>It is understandable that since Prometheus was considered a Titan (distinct from an Olympian) that there would be an absence of evidence, with the exception of Athens, for the direct religious devotion to his worship. Despite his importance to the myths and imaginative literature of ancient Greece, the religious cult of Prometheus during the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Archaic_Greece" title="Archaic Greece">Archaic</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classical_Greece" title="Classical Greece">Classical periods</a> seems to have been limited.<sup id="cite_ref-Dougherty,_Prometheus,_p._46_46-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-Dougherty,_Prometheus,_p._46-46"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>44<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Writing in the 2nd century AD, the satirist <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lucian" title="Lucian">Lucian</a> points out that while temples for the major Olympians were everywhere, none for Prometheus is to be seen.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-47"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>45<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Heracles_freeing_Prometheus,_relief_from_the_Temple_of_Aphrodite_at_Aphrodisias.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="./wikipedia_test_files/Heracles_freeing_Prometheus,_relief_from_the_Temple_of_Aphrodite_at_Aphrodisias.jpg" decoding="async" width="190" height="253" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Heracles_freeing_Prometheus%2C_relief_from_the_Temple_of_Aphrodite_at_Aphrodisias.jpg/330px-Heracles_freeing_Prometheus%2C_relief_from_the_Temple_of_Aphrodite_at_Aphrodisias.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Heracles_freeing_Prometheus%2C_relief_from_the_Temple_of_Aphrodite_at_Aphrodisias.jpg/500px-Heracles_freeing_Prometheus%2C_relief_from_the_Temple_of_Aphrodite_at_Aphrodisias.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1440" data-file-height="1920"></a><figcaption>Heracles freeing Prometheus, relief from the Temple of Aphrodite at <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aphrodisias" title="Aphrodisias">Aphrodisias</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>Athens was the exception; here Prometheus was worshipped alongside <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Athena" title="Athena">Athena</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hephaestus" title="Hephaestus">Hephaestus</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKernyi199758_48-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKer%C3%A9nyi199758-48"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>46<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The altar of Prometheus in the grove of the Academy was the point of origin for several significant processions and other events regularly observed on the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Athenian_calendar" class="mw-redirect" title="Athenian calendar">Athenian calendar</a>. For the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panathenaic_festival" class="mw-redirect" title="Panathenaic festival">Panathenaic festival</a>, arguably the most important civic festival at Athens, a torch race began at the altar, which was located outside the sacred boundary of the city, and passed through the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kerameikos" title="Kerameikos">Kerameikos</a>, the district inhabited by <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pottery_of_ancient_Greece" title="Pottery of ancient Greece">potters</a> and other artisans who regarded Prometheus and Hephaestus as patrons.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-49"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>47<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The race then travelled to the heart of the city, where it kindled the sacrificial fire on the altar of Athena on the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acropolis_of_Athens" title="Acropolis of Athens">Acropolis</a> to conclude the festival.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-50"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>48<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> These footraces took the form of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Relay_(race)" class="mw-redirect" title="Relay (race)">relays</a> in which teams of runners passed off a flaming torch. According to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pausanias_(geographer)" title="Pausanias (geographer)">Pausanias</a> (2nd century AD), the torch relay, called <i>lampadedromia</i> or <i>lampadephoria</i>, was first instituted at Athens in honour of Prometheus.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-51"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>49<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>By the Classical period, the races were run by <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ephebos" title="Ephebos">ephebes</a> also in honour of Hephaestus and Athena.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-52"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>50<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Prometheus's association with fire is the key to his religious significance<sup id="cite_ref-Dougherty,_Prometheus,_p._46_46-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-Dougherty,_Prometheus,_p._46-46"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>44<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and to the alignment with Athena and Hephaestus that was specific to Athens and its "unique degree of cultic emphasis" on honouring <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technology" title="Technology">technology</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-53"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>51<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The festival of Prometheus was the Prometheia ( ). The wreaths worn symbolised the chains of Prometheus.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-54"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>52<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> There is a pattern of resemblances between Hephaestus and Prometheus. Although the classical tradition is that Hephaestus split Zeus's head to allow Athena's birth, that story has also been told of Prometheus. A variant tradition makes Prometheus the son of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hera" title="Hera">Hera</a> like Hephaestus.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKernyi199759_55-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKer%C3%A9nyi199759-55"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>53<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> According to that version, the Giant <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eurymedon_(mythology)" title="Eurymedon (mythology)">Eurymedon</a> raped Hera when she was young, and she had Prometheus. After Zeus married Hera, he threw Eurymedon into Tartarus and punished Prometheus in Caucasus, using the theft of fire as an excuse.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-56"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>54<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-57"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>55<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Ancient artists depict Prometheus wearing the pointed cap of an artist or artisan, like Hephaestus, and also the crafty hero <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Odysseus" title="Odysseus">Odysseus</a>. The artisan's cap was also depicted as worn by the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cabeiri" title="Cabeiri">Cabeiri</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKernyi19975051_58-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKer%C3%A9nyi199750%E2%80%9351-58"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>56<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> supernatural craftsmen associated with a mystery cult known in Athens in classical times, and who were associated with both Hephaestus and Prometheus. <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ker%C3%A9nyi" class="mw-redirect" title="Kernyi">Kernyi</a> suggests that Hephaestus may in fact be the "successor" of Prometheus, despite Hephaestus being himself of archaic origin.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKernyi19975759_59-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKer%C3%A9nyi199757%E2%80%9359-59"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>57<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Pausanias recorded a few other religious sites in Greece devoted to Prometheus. Both <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argos,_Peloponnese" title="Argos, Peloponnese">Argos</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opous" class="mw-redirect" title="Opous">Opous</a> claimed to be Prometheus's final resting place, each erecting a tomb in his honour. The Greek city of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panopeus" title="Panopeus">Panopeus</a> had a cult statue that was supposed to honour Prometheus for having created the human race there.<sup id="cite_ref-titan_45-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-titan-45"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>43<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Aesthetic_tradition_in_Athenian_art">Aesthetic tradition in Athenian art</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Prometheus&action=edit&section=14" title="Edit section: Aesthetic tradition in Athenian art"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>Prometheus's torment by the eagle and his rescue by Heracles were popular subjects in vase paintings of the 6th to 4th centuries BC. He also sometimes appears in depictions of Athena's birth from Zeus's forehead. There was a relief sculpture of Prometheus with Pandora on the base of Athena's cult statue in the Athenian <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parthenon" title="Parthenon">Parthenon</a> of the 5th century BC. A similar rendering is also found at the great altar of Zeus at <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pergamon" title="Pergamon">Pergamon</a> from the second century BC.
</p><p>The event of the release of Prometheus from captivity was frequently revisited on Attic and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Etruscan_art" title="Etruscan art">Etruscan</a> vases between the sixth and fifth centuries BC. In the depiction on display at the Museum of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karlsruhe" title="Karlsruhe">Karlsruhe</a> and in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin" title="Berlin">Berlin</a>, the depiction is that of Prometheus confronted by a menacing large bird (assumed to be the eagle) with Heracles approaching from behind shooting his arrows at it.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-60"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>58<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In the fourth century this imagery was modified to depicting Prometheus bound in a cruciform manner, possibly reflecting an Aeschylus-inspired manner of influence, again with an eagle and with Heracles approaching from the side.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-61"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>59<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Other_authors">Other authors</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Prometheus&action=edit&section=15" title="Edit section: Other authors"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Creation_Prometheus_Louvre_Ma445.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="./wikipedia_test_files/250px-Creation_Prometheus_Louvre_Ma445.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="220" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Creation_Prometheus_Louvre_Ma445.jpg/500px-Creation_Prometheus_Louvre_Ma445.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="2155" data-file-height="1900"></a><figcaption>Creation of humanity by Prometheus as Athena looks on (<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman-era</a> relief, 3rd century AD)</figcaption></figure>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Griepenkerl,_Beseelung_der_menschlichen_Tonfigur_durch_Athena.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="./wikipedia_test_files/Griepenkerl,_Beseelung_der_menschlichen_Tonfigur_durch_Athena.jpg" decoding="async" width="310" height="157" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Griepenkerl%2C_Beseelung_der_menschlichen_Tonfigur_durch_Athena.jpg/500px-Griepenkerl%2C_Beseelung_der_menschlichen_Tonfigur_durch_Athena.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Griepenkerl%2C_Beseelung_der_menschlichen_Tonfigur_durch_Athena.jpg/620px-Griepenkerl%2C_Beseelung_der_menschlichen_Tonfigur_durch_Athena.jpg 2x" data-file-width="750" data-file-height="380"></a><figcaption>Prometheus watches Athena endow his creation with reason (painting by <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christian_Griepenkerl" title="Christian Griepenkerl">Christian Griepenkerl</a>, 1877).</figcaption></figure>
<p>Some two dozen other Greek and Roman authors retold and further embellished the Prometheus myth from as early as the 5th century BC (<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diodorus" class="mw-redirect" title="Diodorus">Diodorus</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Herodorus" title="Herodorus">Herodorus</a>) into the 4th century AD. The most significant detail added to the myth found in, e.g., <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sappho" title="Sappho">Sappho</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aesop" title="Aesop">Aesop</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ovid" title="Ovid">Ovid</a><sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-62"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>60<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> was the central role of Prometheus in the creation of the human race. According to these sources, Prometheus fashioned humans out of clay.
</p><p>Although perhaps made explicit in the <i>Prometheia</i>, later authors such as <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gaius_Julius_Hyginus" title="Gaius Julius Hyginus">Hyginus</a>, the <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bibliotheca_(Pseudo-Apollodorus)" class="mw-redirect" title="Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)">Bibliotheca</a></i>, and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quintus_of_Smyrna" class="mw-redirect" title="Quintus of Smyrna">Quintus of Smyrna</a> would confirm that Prometheus warned Zeus not to marry the sea nymph <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thetis" title="Thetis">Thetis</a>. She is consequently married off to the mortal <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peleus" title="Peleus">Peleus</a>, and bears him a son greater than the father  <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Achilles" title="Achilles">Achilles</a>, Greek hero of the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trojan_War" title="Trojan War">Trojan War</a>. Pseudo-Apollodorus moreover clarifies a cryptic statement (102629) made by Hermes in <i>Prometheus Bound</i>, identifying the centaur <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chiron" title="Chiron">Chiron</a> as the one who would take on Prometheus's suffering and die in his place.<sup id="cite_ref-titan_45-2" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-titan-45"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>43<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Reflecting a myth attested in Greek vase paintings from the Classical period, Pseudo-Apollodorus places the Titan (armed with an axe) at the birth of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Athena" title="Athena">Athena</a>, thus explaining how the goddess sprang forth from the forehead of Zeus.<sup id="cite_ref-titan_45-3" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-titan-45"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>43<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Other minor details attached to the myth include: the duration of Prometheus's torment;<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-63"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>61<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-64"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>62<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> the origin of the eagle that ate the Titan's liver (found in Pseudo-Apollodorus and Hyginus); Pandora's marriage to Epimetheus (found in Pseudo-Apollodorus); myths surrounding the life of Prometheus's son, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deucalion" title="Deucalion">Deucalion</a> (found in Ovid and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apollonius_of_Rhodes" title="Apollonius of Rhodes">Apollonius of Rhodes</a>); and Prometheus's marginal role in the myth of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jason" title="Jason">Jason</a> and the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argonauts" title="Argonauts">Argonauts</a> (found in Apollonius of Rhodes and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gaius_Valerius_Flaccus" class="mw-redirect" title="Gaius Valerius Flaccus">Valerius Flaccus</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-titan_45-4" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-titan-45"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>43<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>"Variants of legends containing the Prometheus motif are widespread in the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Caucasus" title="Caucasus">Caucasus</a>" region, reports Hunt,<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-65"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>63<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> who gave ten stories related to Prometheus from ethno-linguistic groups in the region.
</p><p>Prometheus finally makes an appearance in Athenian playwright <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aristophanes" title="Aristophanes">Aristophanes</a>'s comedy <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Birds_(play)" title="The Birds (play)">The Birds</a></i>, where he is seen living on <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mount_Olympus" title="Mount Olympus">Mount Olympus</a> after the end of his long torture, apparently having reconciled with the other gods. He is presented not as the dauntless rebel who questioned Zeus, but rather as a timid god who goes to negotiate with the titular Birds disguised, so that Zeus will not notice him talking to the enemy.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-66"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>64<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zahhak" title="Zahhak">Zahhak</a>, an evil figure in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Persian_mythology" title="Persian mythology">Iranian mythology</a>, also ends up eternally chained on a mountainside  though the rest of his career is dissimilar to that of Prometheus.<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-67"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>65<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-68"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>66<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-69"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>67<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Late_Roman_antiquity">Late Roman antiquity</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Prometheus&action=edit&section=16" title="Edit section: Late Roman antiquity"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>The three most prominent aspects of the Prometheus myth have parallels within the beliefs of many cultures.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERaggio195848_70-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-FOOTNOTERaggio195848-70"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>68<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> "The Prometheus myth of creation as a visual symbol of the Neoplatonic concept of human nature, illustrated in (many) <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarcophagi" class="mw-redirect" title="Sarcophagi">sarcophagi</a>, was evidently a contradiction of the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christian</a> teaching of the unique and simultaneous act of creation by the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trinity" title="Trinity">Trinity</a>." This Neoplatonism of late Roman antiquity was especially stressed by Tertullian<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-71"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>69<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> who recognised both difference and similarity of the biblical deity with the mythological figure of Prometheus.
</p><p>The imagery of Prometheus and the creation of man used for the purposes of the representation of the creation of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adam" title="Adam">Adam</a> in biblical symbolism is also a recurrent theme in the artistic expression of late Roman antiquity. Of the relatively rare expressions found of the creation of Adam in those centuries of late Roman antiquity, one can single out the so-called "Dogma sarcophagus" of the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lateran_Museum" title="Lateran Museum">Lateran Museum</a> where three figures (commonly taken to represent the theological trinity) are seen in making a benediction to the new man. Another example is found where the prototype of Prometheus is also recognisable in the early Christian era of late Roman antiquity. This can be found upon a sarcophagus of the Church at Mas d'Aire<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-72"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>70<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> as well, and in an even more direct comparison to what Raggio refers to as "a coarsely carved relief from Campli (<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Teramo" title="Teramo">Teramo</a>)<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-73"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>71<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> (where) the Lord sits on a throne and models the body of Adam, exactly like Prometheus". Still another such similarity is found in the example found on a Hellenistic relief presently in the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Louvre" title="Louvre">Louvre</a> in which the Lord gives life to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eve" title="Eve">Eve</a> through the imposition of his two fingers on her eyes recalling the same gesture found in earlier representations of Prometheus.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERaggio195848_70-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-FOOTNOTERaggio195848-70"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>68<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Georgia_(country)" title="Georgia (country)">Georgian</a> mythology, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amirani" title="Amirani">Amirani</a> is a cultural hero who challenged the chief god and, like Prometheus, was chained on the Caucasian mountains where birds would eat his organs. This aspect of the myth had a significant influence on the Greek imagination. It is recognisable from a Greek gem roughly dated to the time of the Hesiod poems, which show Prometheus with hands bound behind his body and crouching before a bird with long wings.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-74"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>72<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> This same image would also be used later in the Rome of the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Augustan_literature_(ancient_Rome)" title="Augustan literature (ancient Rome)">Augustan age</a> as documented by <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adolf_Furtwangler" class="mw-redirect" title="Adolf Furtwangler">Furtwangler</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-75"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>73<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In the often cited and highly publicised interview between <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Campbell" title="Joseph Campbell">Joseph Campbell</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Moyers" title="Bill Moyers">Bill Moyers</a> on Public Television, the author of <i>The Hero with a Thousand Faces</i> presented his view on the comparison of Prometheus and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jesus_Christ" class="mw-redirect" title="Jesus Christ">Jesus</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_76-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-ReferenceA-76"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>74<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Moyers asked Campbell the question in the following words, "In this sense, unlike heroes such as Prometheus or Jesus, we're not going on our journey to save the world but to save ourselves." To which Campbell's well-known response was that, "But in doing that, you save the world. The influence of a vital person vitalizes, there's no doubt about it. The world without spirit is a wasteland. People have the notion of saving the world by shifting things around, changing the rules [...] No, no! Any world is a valid world if it's alive. The thing to do is to bring life to it, and the only way to do that is to find in your own case where the life is and become alive yourself." For Campbell, Jesus suffered mortally on the Cross while Prometheus suffered eternally while chained to a rock, and each of them received punishment for the gift which they bestowed to humankind, for Jesus this was the gift of propitiation from Heaven, and, for Prometheus this was the gift of fire from Olympus.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_76-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-ReferenceA-76"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>74<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>It remains a continuing debate among scholars of comparative religion and the literary reception<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-77"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>75<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> of mythological and religious subject matter as to whether the typology of suffering and torment represented in the Prometheus myth finds its more representative comparisons with the narratives of the Hebrew scriptures or with the New Testament narratives. In the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Book_of_Job" title="Book of Job">Book of Job</a>, significant comparisons can be drawn between the sustained suffering of Job in comparison to that of eternal suffering and torment represented in the Prometheus myth. With Job, the suffering is at the acquiescence of heaven and at the will of the demonic, while in Prometheus the suffering is directly linked to Zeus as the ruler of Olympus. The comparison of the suffering of Jesus after his sentencing in Jerusalem is limited to the three days, from Thursday to Saturday, and leading to the culminating narratives corresponding to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Easter_Sunday" class="mw-redirect" title="Easter Sunday">Easter Sunday</a>. The symbolic import for comparative religion would maintain that suffering related to justified conduct is redeemed in both the Hebrew scriptures and the New Testament narratives, while in Prometheus there remains the image of a non-forgiving deity, Zeus, who nonetheless requires reverence.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_76-2" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-ReferenceA-76"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>74<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Writing in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Late_antiquity" title="Late antiquity">late antiquity</a> of the fourth and fifth century, the Latin commentator Marcus <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maurus_Servius_Honoratus" class="mw-redirect" title="Maurus Servius Honoratus">Servius</a> Honoratus explained that Prometheus was so named because he was a man of great foresight <i>(vir prudentissimus)</i>, possessing the abstract quality of <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Providentia" title="Providentia">providentia</a></i>, the Latin equivalent of Greek <i>promtheia</i> (<span title="Ancient Greek (to 1453)-language text"><span lang="grc">  </span></span>).<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-78"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>76<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Anecdotally, the Roman <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fabulist" class="mw-redirect" title="Fabulist">fabulist</a> <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phaedrus_(fabulist)" title="Phaedrus (fabulist)">Phaedrus</a> (c. 15 BC  c. 50 AD) attributes to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aesop" title="Aesop">Aesop</a> a simple <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Etiology" title="Etiology">etiology</a> for <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homosexuality" title="Homosexuality">homosexuality</a>, in Prometheus's getting drunk while creating the first humans and misapplying the genitalia.<sup id="cite_ref-Dionysos_79-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-Dionysos-79"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>77<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Middle_Ages">Middle Ages</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Prometheus&action=edit&section=17" title="Edit section: Middle Ages"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>Perhaps the most influential book of the Middle Ages upon the reception of the Prometheus myth was the mythological handbook of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fulgentius_Placiades" class="mw-redirect" title="Fulgentius Placiades">Fulgentius Placiades</a>. As stated by <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olga_Raggio" title="Olga Raggio">Raggio</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERaggio195853_80-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-FOOTNOTERaggio195853-80"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>78<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> "The text of Fulgentius, as well as that of (Marcus) Servius [...] are the main sources of the mythological handbooks written in the ninth century by the anonymous <i>Mythographus Primus</i> and <i>Mythographus Secundus</i>. Both were used for the more lengthy and elaborate compendium by the English scholar <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexander_Neckam" title="Alexander Neckam">Alexander Neckman</a> (11571217), the <i>Scintillarium Poetarum</i>, or <i>Poetarius</i>."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERaggio195853_80-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-FOOTNOTERaggio195853-80"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>78<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The purpose of his books was to distinguish allegorical interpretation from the historical interpretation of the Prometheus myth. Continuing in this same tradition of the allegorical interpretation of the Prometheus myth, along with the historical interpretation of the Middle Ages, is the <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genealogia_Deorum_Gentilium" title="Genealogia Deorum Gentilium">Genealogiae</a></i> of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giovanni_Boccaccio" title="Giovanni Boccaccio">Giovanni Boccaccio</a>. Boccaccio follows these two levels of interpretation and distinguishes between two separate versions of the Prometheus myth. For Boccaccio, Prometheus is placed "In the heavens where all is clarity and truth, [Prometheus] steals, so to speak, a ray of the divine wisdom from God himself, source of all Science, supreme Light of every man."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERaggio195854_81-0" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-FOOTNOTERaggio195854-81"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>79<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> With this, Boccaccio shows himself moving from the mediaeval sources with a shift of accent towards the attitude of the Renaissance humanists.
</p><p>Using a similar interpretation to that of Boccaccio, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marsilio_Ficino" title="Marsilio Ficino">Marsilio Ficino</a> in the fifteenth century updated the philosophical and more sombre reception of the Prometheus myth not seen since the time of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plotinus" title="Plotinus">Plotinus</a>. In his book written in 147677 titled <i>Quaestiones Quinque de Mente</i>, Ficino indicates his preference for reading the Prometheus myth as an image of the human soul seeking to obtain supreme truth. As Raggio summarises Ficino's text, "The torture of Prometheus is the torment brought by reason itself to man, who is made by it many times more unhappy than the brutes. It is after having stolen one beam of the celestial light [...] that the soul feels as if fastened by chains and [...] only death can release her bonds and carry her to the source of all knowledge."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERaggio195854_81-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-FOOTNOTERaggio195854-81"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>79<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> This sombreness of attitude in Ficino's text would be further developed later by <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_de_Bouelles" class="mw-redirect" title="Charles de Bouelles">Charles de Bouelles</a>' <i>Liber de Sapiente</i> of 1509 which presented a mix of both scholastic and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neoplatonic" class="mw-redirect" title="Neoplatonic">Neoplatonic</a> ideas.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Renaissance">Renaissance</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Prometheus&action=edit&section=18" title="Edit section: Renaissance"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Piero_di_cosimo,_prometeo.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="./wikipedia_test_files/Piero_di_cosimo,_prometeo.jpg" decoding="async" width="310" height="173" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Piero_di_cosimo%2C_prometeo.jpg/500px-Piero_di_cosimo%2C_prometeo.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Piero_di_cosimo%2C_prometeo.jpg/960px-Piero_di_cosimo%2C_prometeo.jpg 2x" data-file-width="976" data-file-height="546"></a><figcaption>Mythological narrative of Prometheus by <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Piero_di_Cosimo" title="Piero di Cosimo">Piero di Cosimo</a> (1515)</figcaption></figure>
<p>After the writings of both Boccaccio and Ficino in the late Middle Ages about Prometheus, interest in the Titan shifted considerably in the direction of becoming subject matter for painters and sculptors alike. Among the most famous examples is that of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Piero_di_Cosimo" title="Piero di Cosimo">Piero di Cosimo</a> from about 1510 presently on display at the museums of Munich and Strasburg (see Inset). Raggio summarises the Munich version<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-82"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>80<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> as follows; "The Munich panel represents the dispute between Epimetheus and Prometheus, the handsome triumphant statue of the new man, modelled by Prometheus, his ascension to the sky under the guidance of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minerva" title="Minerva">Minerva</a>; the Strasburg panel shows in the distance Prometheus lighting his torch at the wheels of the Sun, and in the foreground on one side, Prometheus applying his torch to the heart of the statue and, on the other, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercury_(mythology)" title="Mercury (mythology)">Mercury</a> fastening him to a tree." All the details are evidently borrowed from <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boccaccio" class="mw-redirect" title="Boccaccio">Boccaccio</a>'s <i>Genealogiae</i>.
</p><p>The same reference to the <i>Genealogiae</i> can be cited as the source for the drawing by <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parmigianino" title="Parmigianino">Parmigianino</a> presently located in the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morgan_Library_%26_Museum" title="Morgan Library & Museum">Morgan Library & Museum</a> in New York City.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-83"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>81<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In the drawing, a very noble rendering of Prometheus is presented which evokes the memory of Michelangelo's works portraying <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jehovah" title="Jehovah">Jehovah</a>. This drawing is perhaps one of the most intense examples of the visualisation of the myth of Prometheus from the Renaissance period.
</p><p>Writing in the late British Renaissance, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Shakespeare" title="William Shakespeare">William Shakespeare</a> uses the Promethean allusion in the famous death scene of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Desdemona" title="Desdemona">Desdemona</a> in his tragedy of <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Othello" title="Othello">Othello</a></i>. Othello in contemplating the death of Desdemona asserts plainly that he cannot restore the "Promethean heat" to her body once it has been extinguished. For Shakespeare, the allusion is clearly to the interpretation of the fire from the heat as the bestowing of life to the creation of man from clay by Prometheus after it was stolen from Olympus. The analogy bears direct resemblance to the biblical narrative of the creation of life in Adam through the bestowed breathing of the creator in Genesis. Shakespeare's symbolic reference to the "heat" associated with Prometheus's fire is to the association of the gift of fire to the mythological gift or theological gift of life to humans.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Post-Renaissance">Post-Renaissance</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Prometheus&action=edit&section=19" title="Edit section: Post-Renaissance"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Thomas_Cole_-_Prometheus_Bound_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="./wikipedia_test_files/250px-Thomas_Cole_-_Prometheus_Bound_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="164" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Thomas_Cole_-_Prometheus_Bound_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/500px-Thomas_Cole_-_Prometheus_Bound_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="4409" data-file-height="2889"></a><figcaption><i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus_Bound_(Thomas_Cole)" title="Prometheus Bound (Thomas Cole)">Prometheus Bound</a></i> by Thomas Cole (1847)</figcaption></figure>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus_in_popular_culture" title="Prometheus in popular culture">Prometheus in popular culture</a></div>
<p>The myth of Prometheus has been a favourite theme of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_art" class="mw-redirect" title="Western art">Western art</a> and literature in the post-<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Renaissance" title="Renaissance">renaissance</a> and post-<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Age_of_Enlightenment" title="Age of Enlightenment">Enlightenment</a> tradition and, occasionally, in works produced outside the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_culture" title="Western culture">West</a>.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Post-Renaissance_literary_arts">Post-Renaissance literary arts</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Prometheus&action=edit&section=20" title="Edit section: Post-Renaissance literary arts"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>For the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Romanticism" title="Romanticism">Romantic era</a>, Prometheus was the rebel who resisted all forms of institutional tyranny epitomised by Zeus  church, monarch, and patriarch. The Romantics drew comparisons between Prometheus and the spirit of the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/French_Revolution" title="French Revolution">French Revolution</a>, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christ" class="mw-redirect" title="Christ">Christ</a>, the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satan" title="Satan">Satan</a> of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Milton" title="John Milton">John Milton</a>'s <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paradise_Lost" title="Paradise Lost">Paradise Lost</a></i>, and the divinely inspired poet or artist. Prometheus is the lyrical "I" who speaks in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goethe" class="mw-redirect" title="Goethe">Goethe</a>'s <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sturm_und_Drang" title="Sturm und Drang">Sturm und Drang</a></i> poem <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus_(Goethe)" title="Prometheus (Goethe)">"Prometheus"</a> (written c. 177274, published 1789), addressing God (as Zeus) in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Misotheist" class="mw-redirect" title="Misotheist">misotheist</a> accusation and defiance. In <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus_Unbound_(Shelley)" title="Prometheus Unbound (Shelley)">Prometheus Unbound</a></i> (1820), a four-act lyrical drama, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Percy_Bysshe_Shelley" title="Percy Bysshe Shelley">Percy Bysshe Shelley</a> rewrites the lost play of Aeschylus so that Prometheus does not submit to Zeus (under the Latin name <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jupiter_(mythology)" class="mw-redirect" title="Jupiter (mythology)">Jupiter</a>), but instead supplants him in a triumph of the human heart and intellect over tyrannical religion. <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lord_Byron" title="Lord Byron">Lord Byron</a>'s poem "Prometheus" also portrays the Titan as unrepentant. As documented by Raggio, other leading figures among the great Romantics included Byron, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Longfellow" class="mw-redirect" title="Longfellow">Longfellow</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nietzsche" class="mw-redirect" title="Nietzsche">Nietzsche</a> as well.<sup id="cite_ref-Raggio_40-1" class="reference"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prometheus#cite_note-Raggio-40"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>38<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mary_Shelley" title="Mary Shelley">Mary Shelley</a>'s 1818 novel <i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frankenstein" title="Frankenstein">Frankenstein</a></i> is subtitled "The Modern Prometheus", in reference to the novel's themes of the over-reaching of modern humanity into dangerous areas of knowledge.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Goethe's_poems"><span id="Goethe.27s_poems"></span>Goethe's poems</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Prometheus&action=edit&section=21" title="Edit section: Goethe's poems"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
